document.docAuthor: De, Thaís M., Bueno-Villegas, Almeida Julián & Rafael, José A.
document.docTitle: Haematotropis disjunctoides De & Bueno-Villegas & Rafael 2021, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of the millipede genus Haematotropis Jeekel, 2000 (Diplopoda, Polydesmida, Aphelidesmidae, Aphelidesminae) with descriptions of thirteen new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic review of the millipede genus Haematotropis Jeekel, 2000 (Diplopoda, Polydesmida, Aphelidesmidae, Aphelidesminae) with descriptions of thirteen new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Adult males of
H . disjunctoides
sp. nov.
differ from other
Haematotropis species
based on the following combination of characters: gonopod with LP1 long and tapered, inclined, apex projected towards the mesal region of gonopod ( Fig. 27A–D ); presence of DP with the apex irregularly bifurcate ( Fig. 27A–C ); solenomere long, taperad, apex truncated, projected towards the ventral region of the body ( Fig. 27A–C ).

, Brasil , Pará , Melgaço , Estação Científica Ferreira Penna , FLONA Caxiuanã ( 01°44’18.02”S , 51º27’48.01”W ), ( MPEG . MYR 082 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 26. Somatic features of
Haematotropis disjunctoides
sp. nov.
, holotype ♂ (MPEG). A. Head and body rings 1–4, dorsal view. B. Head and body rings 1–6, dorsolateral view. C. Body rings 11–14, dorsal view. D. Body rings 18–20, dorsal view. Scale bars: 1.0 mm.

FIGURE 27. Right gonopod of
Haematotropis disjunctoides
sp. nov.
, holotype ♂ (MPEG). A. Mesal view. B. Dorsal view. C. Lateral view. D. Ventral view. Yellow scale indicates when VP1 exceeds the width of ventral region of acropodite. Abbreviations: Ac = acropodite; Ca = cannula; Cx = coxa; DP = Distal Process 1; LP1 = Lateral Process 1; Pf = Prefemur; Sg = spermatic groove; S = Solenomere; Ste = setae; VP1 = Ventral Process 1. Scale bars: 1.0 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Size and form ( holotype ♂ ). Body length = 44 and wide = 7 mm . TL/GW = 6.2.
Coloration (long preserved in 70% ethanol). Head, prozonite, metazonite and telson brown, antennomeres, sides of the metazonite, paranota, posterior region of epiproct and legs orange ( Fig. 26A–D ).
Head. Dorsal surface smooth and shiny, without microgranulations.

Trunk. Collum 2.4 mm long, 6.5 mm wide; dorsal surface of all rings smooth and shiny, without microgranulations; posterolateral margins slightly concave ( Fig. 26A, B ). Rings 2–19: prozonite and metazonite smooth and shiny, without microgranulation in dorsal region of all rings. Anterolateral teeth on paranota of rings 2–4 ( Fig. 2G ). Lateral margins of ring 2 projected posteriad ( Fig. 26A, B ). Gonopodal aperture elliptical, approximately 1.5 mm wide and 0.5 mm long at midpoints. Telson ( Fig. 26D ) smooth and shiny, without microgranulations.
Legs. Smooth and shiny, without microgranulations.

Remarks.
H . disjunctoides
sp. nov.
resembles
H . disjuncta
in the conformation of the gonopods and presence of DP ( Figs 10A–D , 27A–D ). It differs by DP being bifurcate in the apical region and extending beyond the distal region of acropodite. Besides,
H . disjunctoides
sp. nov.
occurs on the south shore of the Amazon River ( Fig. 52 ) while
H . disjuncta
occurs mainly on the north shore ( Fig. 50 ), supporting the separation of the two species.

Etymology. The specific epithet is a combination of the name “
disjuncta
” and the Greek suffix “- oides ”, referring to the similarity of this species to
H . disjuncta
.
